description:
Dichotomopilus funicola is a species of fungus that belongs to the phylum Ascomycota. It is a member of the order Eurotiales and the family Trichocomaceae.

Dichotomopilus funicola is a filamentous fungus that produces septate hyphae. The hyphae exhibit a characteristic dichotomous branching pattern, where the main hyphae split into two equal branches. The fungus can grow on various substrates, including soil, decaying plant material, and other organic matter.

The reproductive structures of Dichotomopilus funicola include conidiophores, which are specialized hyphae that produce asexual spores called conidia. The conidia are small, round, and are typically produced in chains or clusters. The fungus can also produce sexual reproductive structures, such as cleistothecia, which contain ascospores.

Dichotomopilus funicola is commonly found in soil and other terrestrial environments, and it plays a role in the decomposition of organic matter. The species is of interest in the field of mycology, as it contributes to our understanding of the diversity and ecology of filamentous fungi.
